page.title: 18"Bowcombe"-Day in the Life 2
page.content: A typical Summer day in the life of one farmer begins at about 6.30 with a good breakfast so that he can be out by 7 to feed the chickens. At 7.30 he opens the gates, greets the men, and they discuss the jobs for the coming day. He then takes feed out to the cattle in the Land Rover and will spend the morning checking the livestock for disease or ailments. He will then come home for lunch. The afternoon may be taken up with hay-making or silage making until 7 or 8pm when he returns home for supper. "The weather is obviously the most important factor. We like a good cold Winter, it kills off pests. Sun and rain in the Spring and a dry harvest. Of course, you don't often get it. The thing I like about farming is the variety. If you put a lot of effort in you get a lot of satisfaction."
